trans-unit.source: App Registration Portal Help Topics | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: App Registration Portal Help Topics | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: A description of various features in the Microsoft app registration portal.
trans-unit.target: A description of various features in the Microsoft app registration portal.

trans-unit.source: App registration reference
trans-unit.target: App registration reference

trans-unit.source: This document provides context and descriptions of various features found in the Microsoft App Registration Portal [https://apps.dev.microsoft.com](https://apps.dev.microsoft.com).
trans-unit.target: This document provides context and descriptions of various features found in the Microsoft App Registration Portal [https://apps.dev.microsoft.com](https://apps.dev.microsoft.com).

trans-unit.source: My Applications
trans-unit.target: My Applications

trans-unit.source: This list contains all of your applications registered for use with the Azure AD v2.0 endpoint.
trans-unit.target: This list contains all of your applications registered for use with the Azure AD v2.0 endpoint.

trans-unit.source: These applications have the ability to sign in users with both personal accounts from Microsoft account and work/school accounts from Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: These applications have the ability to sign in users with both personal accounts from Microsoft account and work/school accounts from Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about the Azure AD v2.0 endpoint, see our [v2.0 overview](active-directory-appmodel-v2-overview.md).
trans-unit.target: To learn more about the Azure AD v2.0 endpoint, see our [v2.0 overview](active-directory-appmodel-v2-overview.md).

trans-unit.source: These applications can also be used to integrate with the Microsoft account authentication endpoint, `https://login.live.com`.
trans-unit.target: These applications can also be used to integrate with the Microsoft account authentication endpoint, `https://login.live.com`.

trans-unit.source: Live SDK Applications
trans-unit.target: Live SDK Applications

trans-unit.source: This list contains all of your applications registered for use solely with Microsoft account.
trans-unit.target: This list contains all of your applications registered for use solely with Microsoft account.

trans-unit.source: They are not enabled for use with Azure Active Directory whatsoever.
trans-unit.target: They are not enabled for use with Azure Active Directory whatsoever.

trans-unit.source: This is where you will find any applications that had previously been registered with the MSA developer portal at `https://account.live.com/developers/applications`.
trans-unit.target: This is where you will find any applications that had previously been registered with the MSA developer portal at `https://account.live.com/developers/applications`.

trans-unit.source: All functions that you previously performed at `https://account.live.com/developers/applications` can now be performed in this new portal, `https://apps.dev.microsoft.com`.
trans-unit.target: All functions that you previously performed at `https://account.live.com/developers/applications` can now be performed in this new portal, `https://apps.dev.microsoft.com`.

trans-unit.source: If you have any further questions about your Microsoft account applications, please contact us.
trans-unit.target: If you have any further questions about your Microsoft account applications, please contact us.

trans-unit.source: Application Secrets
trans-unit.target: Application Secrets

trans-unit.source: Application secrets are credentials that allow your application to perform reliable [client authentication](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-2.3) with Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: Application secrets are credentials that allow your application to perform reliable [client authentication](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-2.3) with Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: In OAuth & OpenID Connect, an application secrets is commonly referred to as a `client_secret`.
trans-unit.target: In OAuth & OpenID Connect, an application secrets is commonly referred to as a `client_secret`.

trans-unit.source: In the v2.0 protocol, any application that receives a security token at a web addressable location (using an `https` scheme) must use an application secret to identify itself to Azure AD upon redemption of that security token.
trans-unit.target: In the v2.0 protocol, any application that receives a security token at a web addressable location (using an `https` scheme) must use an application secret to identify itself to Azure AD upon redemption of that security token.

trans-unit.source: Furthermore, any native client that recieves tokens on a device will be forbidden from using an application secret to perform client authentication, to discourage the storage of secrets in insecure environments.
trans-unit.target: Furthermore, any native client that recieves tokens on a device will be forbidden from using an application secret to perform client authentication, to discourage the storage of secrets in insecure environments.

trans-unit.source: Each app can contain two valid application secrets at any given point in time.
trans-unit.target: Each app can contain two valid application secrets at any given point in time.

trans-unit.source: By maintaining two secrets, you have the ablilty to perform periodic key rollover across your application's entire environment.
trans-unit.target: By maintaining two secrets, you have the ablilty to perform periodic key rollover across your application's entire environment.

trans-unit.source: Once you have migrated the entirety of your application to a new secret, you may delete the old secret and provision a new one.
trans-unit.target: Once you have migrated the entirety of your application to a new secret, you may delete the old secret and provision a new one.

trans-unit.source: At this time, only two types of application secrets are permitted in the app registration portal.
trans-unit.target: At this time, only two types of application secrets are permitted in the app registration portal.

trans-unit.source: Choosing **Generate New Password** will generate and store a shared secret in the respective data store, which you can use in your application.
trans-unit.target: Choosing **Generate New Password** will generate and store a shared secret in the respective data store, which you can use in your application.

trans-unit.source: Choosing **Generate New Key Pair** will create a new public/private key pair that can be downloaded and used for client authentication to Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: Choosing **Generate New Key Pair** will create a new public/private key pair that can be downloaded and used for client authentication to Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: Profile
trans-unit.target: Profile

trans-unit.source: The profile section of the app registration portal can be used to customize the sign in page for your application.
trans-unit.target: The profile section of the app registration portal can be used to customize the sign in page for your application.

trans-unit.source: At this time you can alter the sign in page's application logo, terms of service URL, and privacy statement.
trans-unit.target: At this time you can alter the sign in page's application logo, terms of service URL, and privacy statement.

trans-unit.source: The logo must be a transparent 48 x 48 or 50 x 50 pixel image in a GIF, PNG or JPEG file that is 15 KB or smaller.
trans-unit.target: The logo must be a transparent 48 x 48 or 50 x 50 pixel image in a GIF, PNG or JPEG file that is 15 KB or smaller.

trans-unit.source: Try changing the values and viewing the resulting sign in page!
trans-unit.target: Try changing the values and viewing the resulting sign in page!

trans-unit.source: Live SDK Support
trans-unit.target: Live SDK Support

trans-unit.source: When you enable "Live SDK Support", any application secrets you create will be provisioned into both the Azure AD and Microsoft Account data stores.
trans-unit.target: When you enable "Live SDK Support", any application secrets you create will be provisioned into both the Azure AD and Microsoft Account data stores.

trans-unit.source: This will allow your application to integrate directly with the Microsoft Account service (login.live.com).
trans-unit.target: This will allow your application to integrate directly with the Microsoft Account service (login.live.com).

trans-unit.source: If you wish to build an app using Microsoft Account directly (as opposed to using the Azure AD v2.0 endpoint), you should make sure that Live SDK Support is enabled.
trans-unit.target: If you wish to build an app using Microsoft Account directly (as opposed to using the Azure AD v2.0 endpoint), you should make sure that Live SDK Support is enabled.

trans-unit.source: Disabling Live SDK support will ensure that the application secret is only written into the Azure AD data store.
trans-unit.target: Disabling Live SDK support will ensure that the application secret is only written into the Azure AD data store.

trans-unit.source: The Azure AD data store incorporates enterprise-grade regulations that allow it to meet certain standards, such as FISMA compliance.
trans-unit.target: The Azure AD data store incorporates enterprise-grade regulations that allow it to meet certain standards, such as FISMA compliance.

trans-unit.source: If you enable Live SDK support, your application may not achieve compliance with some of these standards.
trans-unit.target: If you enable Live SDK support, your application may not achieve compliance with some of these standards.

trans-unit.source: If you only ever plan to use the Azure AD v2.0 endpoint, you can safely disable Live SDK support.
trans-unit.target: If you only ever plan to use the Azure AD v2.0 endpoint, you can safely disable Live SDK support.
